Articles.Content:
Refueling is a standard task in any space program; and since the introduction of funds, we want to refuel at an affordable price. Now, I know as well as anybody else that money is cheap in KSP; other considerations may trump financial concerns. I don't know how to weigh these, though, and from the past few challenges on the topic, I think it's best to not even try. So, this is the simple refueling challenge: the cheapest means of transportation wins.

The Mission: move fuel to orbit. Fill up a vessel or a station, or just deposit a tank in LKO -- I don't care how exactly you do it.

Scoring: (launch_cost - recovered_funds) / tons_of_fuel_delivered. A ton of fuel costs 91 funds on the ground; it can't possibly be cheaper in space. Hint: a Rockomax-64 holds 32 tons, a Kerbodyne-7200 holds 36 tons -- notice a pattern? If you deliver whole tanks, the calculation is easy. Otherwise, each unit on the resource panel is 5kg.

Categories:

  • Stock(ish) -- vessels that are essentially stock craft, or could perform similarly if they were built from stock-only parts.
  • Modded -- anything else, including alternate physics.
  • Low-Tech -- no parts from technologies that cost more than 90 science points. Most importantly, this excludes the LV-N, Turbojets and cubic struts. Only stockish craft, please.

Rules & restrictions:

  • must deliver at least one Orange Tank worth of fuel.
  • for the purposes of this challenge, "FUEL" means liquid fuel & oxidizer in matched proportions.
  • no outright glitch exploits

Submission guidelines:

  • a few good pictures of your vessel -- basically, one should be able to rebuild it from the pictures. Part clipping should not hide important bits, otherwise it's OK.
  • if you're going for a high score, I want to see detailed pictures from the ascent, with at least the navball & resource panel open. Otherwise, a description will do (e.g., "straight up to 10km, then pitch to 45Ã‚Â° until airspeed reaches X, then....").
  • mind the bandwidth: please convert all pictures to JPGs; if your submission consists of more than a few pictures, please use a gallery.
  • provide launch cost, part count, time to space and total amount of fuel delivered -- while scoring is done on money alone, I'm aware that money isn't everything. I don't know how to weigh these other factors relative to funds, but I will keep track of them and post them next to your score. I'll also highlight entries that are especially good or bad in one regard or the other. Please be so kind and state these numbers in your submission; don't leave it to me to piece them together from your screenshots.
  • if you want to enter in the "stockish" category, please explain why the mod parts don't really matter.
  • if you use jets, and if the jets drain from the same tank that is used for delivery, you need to show me how you manage to deliver fuel & oxi in matched proportions.

Additional thoughts:

I hope that this challenge not only attracts highscore hunters, but also a number of useful everyday tankers. The requirement to show part count and time to space is meant to serve that goal, the size limit will hopefully sort out the most useless designs; though I'd be willing to lower it a little if people can convince me that a smaller tanker is still of general utility. I also considered a "King Size" category; right now I have no idea where to draw the line, but if a pattern emerges, I may come back to that idea.

I'll be not too strict about picture proof for everything, really -- if you're not going for an especially high score, I'm basically willing to take your word for it. This is half challenge, half showcase. But you may still want to make your submission a little more detailed, so you can just point to it when doing other challenges.

Edited October 28, 2014 by Laie

Tanker IX: large-to-huge spaceplane, delivers slightly over 162 tons at 114 funds per ton.

262 parts, 910k funds, ~15 Minutes to 70km.

(click for gallery)

The large intakes perform like a quadcoupler with four intakes, that would still be stockish. But the huge procedural wings, loaded down with ~25tons each? Impossible to do in stock, hence a mod vessel.

---

T-80 (it has it's name because it's just a Kerbodyne tank on top of my generic 80t lifter): 102t @ 118funds/t.

(click for gallery)

208 parts, 380k funds, ~15Min to orbit.

The only mod parts are Mechjeb, kOS and possibly KER -- no reason why that thing shouldn't fly just as well without them. Stock(ish) craft.

I think that using a SSTO with a jet engine to get to high atmosphere and a solid fuel booster to get to orbit could be cheaper than jet engine + liquid fuel rocket.

Edited October 29, 2014 by Joonatan1998
